entry.title: Combined summary - Preventing MITM - Providing new nodes with real pubkeys
entry.summary: The discussions revolve around finding solutions to various security threats to the Bitcoin network and the Lightning Network. One of the proposed ways to mitigate risks is to hash and link data to a blockchain while using OP_RETURN outputs. Additionally, there are concerns about the security of the Lightning Network, specifically with fake networks. To avoid this problem, users can perform a test by paying a small amount to merchants and setting the R value as the SHA256 of the decrypted onion message. This process can be repeated daily for a year at minimal cost.In regards to security threats to the Bitcoin network, Mats Jerratsch expresses concern about an attacker MITM'ing internet connections and building a large network that points to the same node, potentially blocking payments. Rusty Russell suggests making it expensive to attack as a good start and proposes using beacons to indicate the size of the network statistically. There are three types of attacks: vandalism, sybil, and pervasive. A MITM attacker can build a local network, all pointing to the same node, and do more than just blocking payments. However, there are ways to tell if a node is on the network or not. To combat dishonest nodes joining the network, it is essential to make it expensive for attackers to attack the network. The Bitcoin network uses checkpoints to protect against such attacks, but these checkpoints are centralized.The Lightning Network has been a topic of discussion regarding its vulnerability to attackers. One participant suggested that an attacker could vandalize the system by opening channels with other nodes, but it was argued that this would be difficult to do as the probability of selecting a vandal node is low. The security of the network depends on knowing public keys of nodes connected to it and it would be best to make it expensive for attackers to attack the system. One potential solution is to create a cost to run or register a node/channel.In an email conversation, Rusty Russell discusses the possibility of Lightning channels between nodes through IOUs and suggests that this approach could lead to fake edges in the routing graph if only dual-signature is used. Regarding the size of the map needed for Lightning, Russell suggests that the concern can be ignored until there are over 10k nodes. The author also discusses finding a solution for malleability in anchor transactions and proposes several options.
